lexUnit.name: side.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: support or oppose in a conflict or dispute.

sentence.text: The football authorities in England accepted the explanation and sided with Gallacher and the Newcastle team , probably as a gesture of national protocol rather than with the conviction that the Scot was telling the truth .
They now began to side with the extreme wing of the pied noir integrationist movement , which openly called for his overthrow .
She 'd sided with my parents a couple of years before when I 'd been thinking of a career as an artist , and they were opposed to that …
For the first time Michael sided with him .
The implication is that Pope John sided with the minority at the first session and was ` upset " ( as the minority often asserted ) at the rejection of such excellent drafts .
Brenda sided with Belinda , Liese with Apricot .
The skins who sided with the punks were a new breed , who wished to be seen as more anarchical and more shocking than the punks .
Offwood sided with the Ainsworthians until 1617 , when he was excommunicated for quarrelling with Thomas Stafford , another church member who was seeking to marry Offwood 's daughter , Susanna .
But Cohn-Casson also found it impossible to side uncritically with Jews , because to do so would deny modern thinking , by placing tribal loyalties above the mandates of science .
He , however , was unpopular in Italy , and was soon opposed by his own general , Ricimer , who sided instead with Majorian .
Essentially the disputes which led local men to side predominantly with Parliament in the 1640s grew from their ideas of social control .
